trans-unit.source: Represents the horizontal and vertical line segments that are dynamically created in the user interface (UI) to assist in the design-time layout of controls in a container.
This class cannot be inherited.
The following table lists the common modes that visual design tools support to assist you with positioning and sizing controls on a design surface.

|Mode|Description| |----------|-----------------| |Freeform|Enables you to freely lay out controls.| |Grid|Displays a static overlaid grid that assists you in laying out controls.| |Snapline|Displays guide lines that assist you in laying out the container's controls relative to each other.
Snaplines originate from controls and their container.| The SnapLine class and related types help support the Snapline mode.
Snaplines are generated dynamically and automatically as a control edge moves near another control or near the boundaries of its container.
This can occur when a control is added from the toolbox, or moved or resized by mouse operations or keyboard commands.
Controls typically have both horizontal and vertical snaplines defined; for rectangular controls, these typically extend from all four edges.
The SnapLine class uses only a few properties to describe each snapline, as shown in the following table.

|Property|Description| |--------------|-----------------| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.SnapLineType%2A>|Specifies the location and direction of the line with respect to its associated control.

Typically, only snaplines of similar types will auto-align to each other.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.Offset%2A>|Specifies the distance in pixels from the origin, which is the upper-left corner of the control, to where the snapline starts.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.Priority%2A>|Specifies the relative importance of the snapline.

During any given layout decision point, only the snaplines that are active and have the highest priority are displayed.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.Filter%2A>|Defines custom categories of snaplines.

This is an optional string.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.IsHorizontal%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.IsVertical%2A>|Indicates whether a snapline has horizontal or vertical orientation, respectively.| The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner> class stores snaplines for its corresponding control type in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner.SnapLines%2A> property.

This base class handling of snaplines will suffice for the majority of controls, as it defines the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType> snaplines, which are aligned along the edges of the control.

When you are developing a custom control, if this default organization does not suffice, override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner.SnapLines%2A> property of the class derived from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner>.
For example, you may want to align the horizontal snaplines of text-based controls, such as labels, with the top and base lines of the text (instead of the top and bottom edges of the control).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.SnapLineType%2A> class cannot be derived from.
There is extensive support for this feature in Visual Studio, see [Walkthrough: Arranging Controls on Windows Forms Using Snaplines](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref> class using the specified snapline type and offset.

This constructor sets the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.Filter%2A> property to `null` and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.Priority%2A> property to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLinePriority>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType"></xref> to create.
Describes the relative position and orientation of the snapline.
The position of the snapline, in pixels, relative to the upper-left origin of the owning control.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref> class using the specified snapline type, offset, and filter name.
This constructor sets the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.Priority%2A> property to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLinePriority>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType"></xref> to create.
Describes the relative position and orientation of the snapline.
The position of the snapline, in pixels, relative to the upper-left origin of the owning control.
A <xref:System.String> used to specify a programmer-defined category of snaplines.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref> class using the specified snapline type, offset, and priority.
This constructor sets the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.Filter%2A> property to `null`.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType"></xref> to create.
Describes the relative position and orientation of the snapline.
The position of the snapline, in pixels, relative to the upper-left origin of the owning control.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLinePriority"></xref> of the snapline.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref> class using the specified snapline type, offset, filter name, and priority.
This constructor sets all of the properties of a snapline to programmer-supplied values.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType"></xref> to create.
Describes the relative position and orientation of the snapline.
The position of the snapline, in pixels, relative to the upper-left origin of the owning control.
A <xref:System.String> used to specify a programmer-defined category of snaplines.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLinePriority"></xref> of the snapline.
Adjusts the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.Offset*> property of the snapline.
The offset of a snapline is the distance, in pixels, that the snapline is located from the associated control's upper-left origin.

Although the offset can be set to any integer value, typically the snaplines retain the spatial relationships implied by their <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.SnapLineType%2A> property value.
The number of pixels to change the snapline offset by.
Gets the programmer-defined filter category associated with this snapline.
The Filter property is used to define custom categories of snaplines.
Only snaplines with the same filter name are able to snap to each other.
This property can be used in custom control designers to expose different categories of snaplines depending upon the state of the control or the type of operation being performed.
For example, round controls could offer a custom snapline with the filter value of "Center".
This property is initialized during construction and cannot be changed thereafter.
A <xref:System.String> that defines the filter category.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value indicating whether the snapline has a horizontal orientation.

The following snapline types are horizontal: <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the snapline is horizontal; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value indicating whether the snapline has a vertical orientation.

The following snapline types are vertical: <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType>.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the snapline is vertical; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets the number of pixels that the snapline is offset from the origin of the associated control.
The origin of a control is the upper-left point of the control.
A single offset can describe the position of a snapline, because vertical snaplines may have only a nonzero x-axis offset, whereas horizontal snaplines may only have a nonzero y-axis offset.
The Offset property is initialized at construction time, but it can be changed thereafter with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine.AdjustOffset%2A> method.
The offset, in pixels, of the snapline.
Gets a value indicating the relative importance of the snapline.
The Priority property establishes categories of importance for the snaplines associated with a control.
The Windows Forms Designer uses this property to determine which snaplines to display during a control addition, resize, or move operation.
For more information, see the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLinePriority> enumeration.
This property is initialized during construction and cannot be changed thereafter.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLinePriority"></xref> that represents the priority category of a snapline.

Returns a value indicating whether the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref> should snap to another <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref>.
The specified <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref> to which the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref> is expected to snap.
if line1 should snap to line2; otherwise, .
Gets the type of a snapline, which indicates the general location and orientation.
Visual designers use the SnapLineType property to direct snap alignment operations.
Typically only snaplines that are similarly oriented can snap to each other.

For example, two snaplines of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType> can snap together, but a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType> and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType> snapline cannot.
This property is initialized during construction and cannot be changed thereafter.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLineType"></xref> that represents the orientation and general location, relative to control edges, of a snapline.
Returns a string representation of the current snapline.
This method returns a string that contains details about the type, offset, priority, and filter values of the snapline.
A <xref:System.String> that represents the current <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref>.
